Award.AwardTitle: Analysis of Cirrus Clouds and Atmospheric Humidity with Cloud Resolving Numerical Model Calculations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Clouds pose a major challenge for global climate models, and uncertainties remain from process level understanding of cloud formation to processes that control the global cloud distribution. This project provides high-resolution numerical model simulations that will advance our theoretical understanding of the dominant factors controlling the genesis and global distribution of cirrus clouds, their impact on atmospheric water vapor, and the radiative impact of the combined cloud/vapor system. The role of cirrus clouds in dehydration of the upper troposphere remains not well quantified.

The project's focus is on the importance of the interaction between cirrus clouds and the environment, and aims to bridge the gap in numerical modeling between the detailed study of individual cirrus clouds and the full domain-wide properties of the cloud field. The objectives of this project are (i) to determine the relative importance of nucleation processes (traditionally a focus of cirrus research) to post-nucleation processes (such as gravitational redistribution of condensate) on the cloud's microphysical properties; (ii) to quantify the impact of the cloud microphysical properties on the domain-wide moisture field (which in turn may feed back onto cloud formation) and domain-wide cloud field properties (such as occurrence frequency and ice water path); and (iii) to put the results from (i) and (ii) in context with the dynamical constraints on conditions favorable for cloud formation. The project focuses specifically on the role of cirrus in the tropical tropopause layer (TTL). Results from the project will contribute to improved understanding of the role of cirrus clouds for the regulation of water vapor in the TTL and stratosphere (with important consequences for the radiative forcing of climate, and stratospheric chemistry). The TTL is also in several ways ideal to study cirrus clouds and their interaction with the environment as both the dynamical conditions favoring in-situ cirrus cloud formation, as well as the large-scale structure of the TTL, can be reasonably well idealized.

The objectives of the project are addressed with a wide range of numerical experiments with a cloud-resolving model that is scalable from very high resolution simulations at cloud scale to simulations of the entire tropics.

Intellectual Merit :

Insights from this project will help to improve parameterizations for general circulation models, leading to improved climate predictions.
Broader Impacts :
This project will help to reduce uncertainties in climate predictions, providing policy makers with more accurate information on future climate. The project will support a designated post-doctoral researcher with excellent reputation and a graduate student, thus training the next generation of cloud modeling specialists. Further, the PI will actively promote involvement of undergraduate students (in the form of Junior and Senior Theses) at Princeton University, thereby providing a first-hand experience and better understanding of climate science to a body of students that frequently follows careers in industry, finance and government.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We use numerical models to improve our understanding of dehydration in the tropical tropopause layer (TTL) by cirrus clouds. Dehydration in the TTL is of importance for the global climate because it regulates the amount of moisture that enters the stratosphere. The stratosphere, the atmospheric layer overlying the troposphere, is very dry. This is a consequence of the temperature decrease with height up to the tropopause, and subsequent increase with height in the stratosphere. Most air enters the stratosphere across the tropopause in the tropics, where the tropopause is much higher and colder than over the subtropics, and the temperatures there strongly constrain the amount of water vapor entering the stratosphere. Because the stratosphere is dry, even minor changes therein do exert a substantial radiative forcing that will lead to a global surface temperature response. Further, stratospheric water plays an important role in the stratospheric ozone chemistry, in particular also in the mechanism that leads to the so-called “ozone hole”.

It is understood since the 1940’s that the temperatures around the tropical tropopause strongly constrain stratospheric humidity, but quantification of the physical processes remains challenging. It is unclear how much of the stratospheric water entered the stratosphere in the form of vapor, and how much  entered as ice (subsequently sublimated in the stratosphere). For decades the prevailing perception was that the stratosphere is drier than expected if only vapor enters the stratosphere, but more recent estimates based on newer, more accurate temperature and wind data (so called “analysed” meteorological data) suggest that the stratosphere may be moister than expected from vapor alone. Re-evaporation of ice could be a major contributor.

The question therefore is how efficiently the frequently observed cirrus (ice) clouds in the TTL around the tropopause dehydrate the air in that layer. The dehydration efficiency depends on how fast the ice crystals sediment relative to the time that the air is subject to a given temperature. Neglecting atmospheric mixing, an air parcel’s humidity is given by the minimum vapor pressure that it has encountered  if the dehydration efficiency is high. The fall speed of ice depends on the size of the crystal, which in turn depends on the amount of water available and the number of crystals. Cirrus clouds around the tropical tropopause have often little ice water content, and accurate knowledge of particle sizes is required to correctly estimate their dehydration efficiency. Due to limitations arising from computational resources, the high-resolution numerical models required to address this problem can only be run in idealized configurations. Specifically, we use numerical models that represent a 2-dimensional (height/horizontal dimension) domain with conditions that are similar to those typically found in the TTL.

With the project support provided, we run the first steady-state, highly detailed simulations of cirrus clouds in the TTL formed by in-situ nucleation (i.e. not resulting from deep convection). Being able to run the model into equilibrium where clouds continuously form and disappear is a step forward as it allows a better estimate of their net effect on stratospheric humidity. Since the ice nucleation process is important in determining the ice number density and size, we ran the model with detailed cloud microphysics, and carried out experiments with both homogeneous and heterogeneous nucleation. The two processes are thought to result in clouds with different ice number densities. Since there are fewer heterogeneous nuclei, the dehydration efficiency may be higher.

Our numerical model calculations provided somewhat unexpected results. First, it appears that also homogeneous nucleation at the low temperatures around the tropical tropopause can result in relatively low ice crystal number densities. Second, irrespective of the nucleation process (and other parameters), the clouds formed in the model always dehydrate air entering the stratosphere remarkably efficient. In fact, it seems difficult that in-situ formed cirrus clouds can fill the aformentioned gap. The question therefore is whether the idealized model setup may miss important aspects, and to what extent ice originating from deep convection can contribute to stratospheric humidity.

To address these questions, we seek to determine cloud properties using lidar measurements from the space-borne CALIPSO mission, which also measures thin cirrus. However, the optical lidar data needs conversion to geophysical quantities. Since we are interested in the ice sedimentary mass flux, uncertainties in the particle size distributions used for this conversion are a major impediment: A small error in the particle size distribution translates into a large error in ice sedimentation mass flux. Since the size distribution is not directly measured by the lidar, errors and potentially large biases can result from using parametrized size distributions. We therefore invest efforts to improve the characterization of the resulting errors and biases. This analysis is close to completion, and the new insights allow us to formulate improved model boundary conditions, and methods to upscale the results from the idealized numerical model simulations.
